content: The Act titled "Joint Task Force to Combat Opioid Trafficking Act of 2018" authorizes the establishment of a Joint Task Force to counter opioids. The Homeland Security Act of 2002 is amended to enhance the integration of border security operations to detect and prevent narcotics like fentanyl from entering the United States. Additionally, the Act allows the Director of a Joint Task Force to engage with the private sector. The Homeland Security Act of 2002 is amended to allow the Director of a Joint Task Force to engage with the private sector for the mission, without being subject to the Federal Advisory Committee Act. The Secretary can arrange for temporary assignment of private sector employees to the Joint Task Force. The Homeland Security Act of 2002 allows the Director of a Joint Task Force to engage with the private sector without being subject to the Federal Advisory Committee Act. Private sector employees can be temporarily assigned to the Joint Task Force for up to 2 years, with the private sector organization responsible for all costs. The Secretary may collaborate with task forces outside DHS for the mission of the Joint Task Force. The Homeland Security Act of 2002 allows private sector employees to be temporarily assigned to a Joint Task Force for up to 2 years. Section 708(c) of the Act is amended to update a reference. SEC. 3. NOTIFICATION; REPORTING. The Secretary of Homeland Security must make a determination within 90 days of the enactment of the Act regarding the establishment of a Joint Task Force under section 708 of the Homeland Security Act of 2002. If established, a written notification must be submitted to the relevant committees in Congress. The Secretary of Homeland Security must establish a Joint Task Force under section 708 of the Homeland Security Act of 2002 to address the detection and prevention of narcotics, including fentanyl and synthetic opioids, from entering the United States. This task force must conduct a gap analysis of needed resources and collaborate with other federal, state, local, and tribal entities. The Secretary of Homeland Security must establish a Joint Task Force under section 708 of the Homeland Security Act of 2002 to address the detection and prevention of narcotics, including fentanyl and synthetic opioids, from entering the United States. The task force collaborates with various federal, state, local, tribal, territorial, and international entities, including the United States Postal Service and the United States Postal Inspection Service. Reports must assess the Joint Task Force's activities and its impact on enhancing the Department's efforts in detecting, disrupting, and preventing narcotics from entering the country.
